interlinear-text.item: ELA Wakhi Across Europe and Asia

phrase.item: My name is Shakir Ahmed.
In Pakistan, there is a small village called Gulmit, I was born there.
When I was a child, three years old, my parents [moved] from there to Gilt.
We moved from there with our whole family.
We went there as children, we studied and received our education there.
I went up to seventh grade there. And after [high school] to continue my education I attended military university.
I studied five years there.
After that, again for education reasons, I went to Lahore, a big city in Pakistan.
I attended university there and got an education.
After that I came back to my village, Gilt.
I worked there for three years.
It was in the field of natural disaster [readiness], how to help people when a disaster happens with what they should do.
So for that my job was to draw maps for them, how a disaster can comes and the ways we can protect ourselves, what are the best places to go for protection.
Within those three years I got a chance, I found a scholarship and came to Turkey. Now I am doing my Master's degree at the University of Istanbul.
I have been here for three years. I have graduated,
and now I will be leaving here. From here I will return to my village, to my people, Inshallah.
l will join my people very soon.

As for the Wakhi language, among other [languages], as for its importance, I would say that because I have been far from village [homeland], I have left the Wakhi language far behind. I didn't know enough.
But I really have a desire to try so that I can talk to my people.
Because with our language from childhood on, we only heard our language from our fathers and grandfathers,
orally only.
We didn't see a written form of our language.
Nowadays there are many people working on the Wakhi language, many students and organizations are working on it. As our language is about to die, in order to preserve it
they are really trying. First of all, I would really praise them, that they are working so hard on that.
And it is necessary for our language, that through people, ‎‎it passes from old to young generation.
Also books will be available in schools, as well as videos on social media.

These different type of short stories reach people even those of different nationalities, as from Pakistan, Badakhshan [Tajikistan], and Afghanistan, living in different places, as they go abroad or somewhere else, they get together and keep their Wakhi language alive.
They get together and work together
and on my own behalf, I give praise for this. And Inshallah, and however much I can, I will work with them for the Wakhi language,
with whatever opportunities I get I will serve.
This language we should know and after from us to our children, and to their children, it should be kept safe.
So in this way the language will remain alive.
So I believe for that reason we should do our best to work on it.
Thank you very much!
